You studied the way of Yao, Shun, Zhou, and Kong when you were a young adult.
But now you abandon it.
And learn the techniques of the barbarians.
Aren't you confused?
Mouzi said:
This is just idle talk from when I had not yet understood the great Way.
If you can be said to see the splendor of ritual and law,
then you are ignorant of the reality of morality and virtue.
You peek at the brightness of torches,
but have not yet seen the sun in the heavenly court.
What Confucius said is to correct worldly laws.
What Meng Ke said is to detest being biased.
In the past, Confucius wanted to live among the Ji barbarians and said:
'What is the point of a gentleman living there?'ğŸ”½When Zhongni was not accepted in Lu and Wei,
and Meng Ke was not employed in Qi and Liang,
how could they serve the barbarians?
Yu came out of the Western Qiang and became a sage and wise man.
Gu Sou gave birth to Shun and was stubborn and foolish.
Yu was born in the state of Di and became the hegemon of Qin.
Guan and Cai spread rumors from the Yellow River and Luo River.
The classics say:
The North Star
is in the center of the sky.
It is to the north of humans.
Judging from this,
China may not be the center of the world.
What the Buddhist scriptures say is
that all creatures in the universe, above and below, belong to the Buddha.
Therefore, I revere and study it.
Why should I abandon the way of Yao, Shun, Zhou, and Kong?
Gold and jade do not injure each other.
Blue and green do not obstruct each other.
When calling others deluded, are you not deluding yourself?
Question:
It is like giving away one's father's wealth to strangers.
It cannot be called generosity.
While one's parents are still alive, killing oneself to replace others.
It cannot be called benevolence.
Now the Buddhist scriptures say:
Prince SudÄna.
Giving the father's wealth to distant people,
Giving the country's precious elephants as gifts to enemies,
Giving one's wife and children to others,
Not respecting one's parents,
But respecting others,
Is called going against propriety.
Not loving one's parents,
But loving others,
Is called going against virtue.
Sudatta is unfilial and unrighteous,
Yet the Buddha's teachings revere him.
Isn't this strange?
Mouzi said:
The meaning of the Five Classics establishes the eldest son as the heir.
King Wen of Zhou saw the ambition of King Cheng,
Changing the youngest son to be the heir.
Thus establishing the Zhou dynasty.
Leading to the establishment of peace.
The meaning of taking a wife must be reported to one's parents.
Shun took a wife without reporting it, establishing the great order.
A loyal person must be invited.
A wise minister waits for a summons.
Yi Yin carried a tripod to offer to Tang.
Ning Qi knocked on the horns to request an audience with Qi.
Tang thus became the king.
Qi thus became hegemon.
The propriety between men and women does not allow direct contact.
When his sister-in-law was drowning, he gave her his hand.
Judging the urgency,
if he saw the greater,
he did not stick to the lesser.
How could a great man be bound by convention?
Sudatta saw the impermanence of the world and that wealth is not one's own treasure, so he indulged in giving generously to achieve the great Way.
His father's country received his blessings,
and enemy armies could not enter.
When he attained Buddhahood,
his parents and brothers all attained liberation from the world.
This is not being filial,
this is not being benevolent.
Who is benevolent and filial?
A question was asked:
The Buddhist Way values non-action, giving generously, and upholding precepts with utmost care as if treading on thin ice.
Now monks indulge in alcohol,
some keep wives and children,
buy cheap and sell expensive,
and exclusively engage in deception.
This is the greatest fraud in the world,
yet the Buddhist Way calls it non-action?
Mouzi replied:
Gongshu could give people axes, saws, ropes, and compasses,
But it cannot make people put it into practice.
The sages can teach people the Way.
But they cannot make people tread and practice it.
Gao Yao and Dayi could punish thieves,
But they could not make the greedy become Yi and Qi.
The five punishments can execute the unruly,
But they cannot make bad sons become Zeng and Min.ğŸ”½Yao could not transform Dan Zhu,
And the Duke of Zhou could not instruct Guan and Cai.ğŸ”½How could it be that the teachings of the Tang dynasty are not comprehensive,
And the Way of the Zhou is not complete?
But there is nothing like an evil person.
It is like a person in the world who studies the seven classics,
But is confused by wealth and sex.
Can he be called a deviant and licentious person in the six arts?
Although the Lord of the River is divine,
He does not drown people on land.
Although a gale is swift,
It cannot make the still water raise dust.
One should blame people for not being able to practice it,
How can one say that the Buddhist Way is evil?
Question:
Confucius said:
Luxury leads to laxity, while frugality leads to firmness.
Whether to be polite or impolite, it is better to be firm.
Shusun said:
Those who are frugal are respectful in virtue.
Those who are extravagant are greatly evil.
Now Buddhists give empty wallets as donations.
They consider it honorable to give all their possessions to others.
How can there be blessings in this?
Mouzi said:ğŸ”½That was a time.
This is a time.
The words of Confucius
criticize extravagance without propriety.
Shusun's discussion
scolds Gong's carving of pillars.
It is not a prohibition against giving.
Shun tilled Mount Li.
His kindness did not reach the towns and villages.
Taigong slaughtered cattle.
His kindness did not reach his wife and children.
When they were employed,
his kindness flowed to the eight wildernesses and his kindness was bestowed upon the four seas.
Wealthy people with many goods are valued for their ability to give. Poor and destitute people who are repeatedly empty are valued for their practice of the Way.
Xu You did not covet the four seas.
Bo Yi did not enjoy his country.
Yu Qing gave up the fief of ten thousand households.
To save the urgent needs of the poor.
Each has its own aspiration.
Xi Fu Rong received the favor of a gourd meal.
He preserved the place where he lived.
Xuan Meng, because of a single meal,
Saved his body that was not despised.
The hidden giving came unexpectedly.
The manifest reward is as bright as the sun.
How much more so for emptying one's family wealth and giving rise to good intentions.
The merit is lofty like Mount Song and Mount Tai.
Vast like the rivers and seas.
Those who harbor goodness will be rewarded with blessings.
Those who harbor evil will be punished with misfortune.
There has never been one who plants rice and gets wheat,
Or who creates misfortune and gains blessings.
Question:
As for affairs, nothing surpasses sincerity.
As for explanations, nothing surpasses truth.
Laozi removes flowery and decorative words.
He esteems plain and simple language.
The Buddha's scriptures do not point to things.
They merely extensively employ metaphors.
Metaphors are not the essence of the Way.
Combining differences to form sameness is not the subtlety of things.
Although the words are many and the language is extensive,
It is like a cartload of jade shavings, which is not considered precious.
Mouzi said:
Things that have been seen together can be discussed with facts.
One person sees, one person does not see,
it is difficult to have sincere discussions.
In the past, people had not seen a qilin.
They asked those who had seen it, What is a qilin like?
Those who had seen it said,
A qilin is like a qilin.
The questioner said,
If I had seen a qilin,
I would not ask you.
But you say a qilin is like a qilin, how can I understand that?
Those who had seen it said,
A qilin has the body of a deer, the tail of a cow, the hooves of a deer, and the back of a horse.
The questioner did not understand.
Confucius said,
A person who does not become angry when others do not know him,
isn't he a true gentleman?
Laozi said,
Between heaven and earth, it is like a bellows.
He also said,
Comparing the Way to the world,
it is like a river valley to the great rivers and seas. How can it be adorned?
The Analects said,
Governing with virtue is like the Northern Dipper.
Drawing on the heavens to compare it to people.
Zixia said:
It is like distinguishing grasses and trees by their regions.
Of the three hundred poems,
They draw things together by type.
From the various masters' prophecies and secret essentials of the sages,
There is none that does not draw analogies and use metaphors.
Why do you alone dislike the Buddha's sutras using analogies and metaphors?
A question was asked:
In a person's life in the world,
There is none who does not like wealth and status and dislike poverty and lowliness.
They enjoy pleasure and dislike hard work.
The Yellow Emperor nourished his nature,
Taking the five delicacies as supreme.
Confucius said:
Food is not despised for its refinement, nor is soup despised for its subtlety.
Now Å›ramaá¹‡as wear red cloth,
Eating only once a day,
Closing off the six senses,
Spending their entire lives like this.
What is the point of this?
Mouzi said:
Wealth and status are what people desire,
But if they are not obtained through the right way, they are not to be enjoyed.
Poverty and lowliness are what people dislike.
But they do not go away by means of the Way.
Laozi said:
The five colors make people's eyes blind.
The five notes make people's ears deaf.
The five flavors make people's mouths dry.
Chasing and hunting make people's hearts go crazy.
Difficult-to-obtain goods make people's conduct go wrong.
The sage is for the belly, not for the eyes.
How can these words be false?
Liu Xia Hui did not change his conduct for the position of the three offices.
Duan Gan Mu did not change his body for the wealth of Wei Wen.
Xu You and Shi lived in trees.
They considered themselves at ease in the imperial palace.
Yi and Qi starved on Mount Shouyang.
They considered themselves full with Wen and Wu.
They each just got what they wanted.
What is the point of having more?
Question:
If the Buddhist scriptures are profound, wonderful, and elegant,ğŸ”½Why don't you discuss them in court?
Discuss them with your ruler and father?
Cultivate it in the inner chambers.
Connect with it in friendships.
Why study the classics and read the works of various masters?
Mouzi said:
You have not reached its source,
Yet you ask about its flow.ğŸ”½Setting up sacrificial vessels and dishes at the gate of a fortress,ğŸ”½Raising banners and flags in the court hall,
Wearing fox fur to receive guests from the borderlands,
Wearing thick fur to drive the Yellow Bell,
It is not that they are not beautiful,
But they are out of place and not timely.
Therefore, holding the techniques of Confucius,
Entering the gate of Shang Yang,
Bringing the teachings of Mencius,
Going to the court of Su Qin and Zhang Yi,
The merit is not even a fraction,
The faults are a full measure.
Laozi said:
The superior person hears the Way and diligently practices it.
The middling person, upon hearing the Way, is sometimes doubtful and sometimes not.
The inferior person, upon hearing the Way, laughs loudly at it.
I fear great laughter, so I do not discuss it.
Thirst need not wait for rivers and streams.
And drinking the water of the well, what is not satisfied?
Therefore, I have edited the sutras and commentaries again.
Question:
The Buddha's teachings were first heard in China.
Where did they come from?
Mouzi replied:
In the past, Emperor Xiaoming
had a dream of a divine person.
His body had sunlight and flew in front of the palace.
He was delighted.
The next day, he asked the ministers in detail:
What kind of spirit is this?
The knowledgeable Fu Yi said:
Your subject has heard that in India there are those who have attained the Way called Buddhas.
They fly in the sky.
Their bodies have sunlight.
It is probably their spirit.
Thereupon, the emperor awoke.
He sent eighteen people including Cai Yin, a Gentleman-in-Attendance, Qin Jing, a Court Gentleman for Ceremonials, and Wang Zun, a student of the Imperial University,
to the country of Yuezhi.
They copied the Buddhist sutras in forty-two chapters.
They were stored in the fourteenth chamber of the Stone Chamber of the Lantai.
At that time, a Buddhist temple was built outside Yongmen, to the west of Luoyang City.
On the walls, he painted a thousand carriages and ten thousand cavalry circumambulating the stupa three times.
Moreover, in the Qingliang Terrace of the Southern Palace,
and on the Kaiyang Gate, he made Buddha images.
During Emperor Ming's time, the Mausoleum of Longevity was constructed in advance.
Xianjie also made a Buddhist stupa on it.
At that time, the country was prosperous, the people were at peace, and the distant barbarians admired the Way.
Learners were thus nourished.
Question:
Laozi said:ğŸ”½The wise do not speak.
Those who speak are not wise.
He also said:ğŸ”½Great eloquence is like silence.
Great skill is like clumsiness.
The gentleman is ashamed of speaking more than he acts.
If Å›ramaá¹‡as have the ultimate Way,ğŸ”½why not sit and practice it?
Why do they discuss right and wrong and argue about what is crooked and straight?
I think this is a thief of virtuous conduct.
Mouzi said:
Next spring will be greatly hungry. Do not eat this autumn.
Huangzhong should be cold. Bin should wear a heavy fur robe.
Although preparing in advance is not foolish, it cannot avoid being foolish.
What Laozi said
Refers to those who have attained the Way.
How can those who have not attained the Way know it?
When the Great Way is spoken of, the world delights in it.
Isn't this great eloquence?
Didn't Laozi say:
When the task is accomplished, the body withdraws - this is the way of Heaven.
Since the body has already withdrawn,
What more is there to say?
The Å›ramaá¹‡as of today have not yet attained the Way.
How can they not speak?
Laozi also speaks.
If he did not speak, how could the five thousand words be recorded?
If he knew but did not speak, that would be acceptable.
Since he cannot know and cannot speak, he is a fool.
Therefore, one who can speak but not practice is the teacher of the country.ğŸ”½One who can practice but not speak is the servant of the country.
One who can both practice and speak is the treasure of the country.
Each of the three ranks has its own contribution.
What is the thief of virtue?
Only one who cannot speak
And also cannot practice,
Is called a thief.
Question:
As the son said.
The disciples should only study eloquence and cultivate debate.
How can they still regulate their emotions and nature and practice the Way and virtue?
Mouzi said:
How difficult to understand!
Words and discussions each have their time.
Qu Yuan said:
When the country has the Way, be straightforward.
When the country has no Way, roll it up and keep it in mind.
When the country has the Way, be wise.
When the country has no Way, be foolish.
Confucius said:ğŸ”½If one can speak with someone but does not, one loses the person.
If one cannot speak with someone but does, one loses one's words.
Therefore, wisdom and foolishness each have their time.
Discussions each have their meaning.
Why should one not practice what should be discussed?
Question:
How is it that the Buddha's Way is supreme, wonderful, effortless, and peaceful?
Many scholars in the world slander and disparage it, saying:
Its teachings are vast and difficult to use.
It is empty and difficult to believe. Why is this so?
Mouzi said:
The most exquisite taste does not agree with the mouths of the masses.
The greatest sound is not comparable to the ears of the masses.
Setting up the Xianchi and playing the great chapters,
Emitting the Xiao and Shao melodies, singing the nine accomplishments,
No one can harmonize with it.
Playing the Zheng, Wei, and other strings and songs, the music of the times,
One will certainly not clap one's hands without intending to.
Therefore Song Yu said:ğŸ”½A guest sang in Ying,
Singing the Xiaoli song.
A thousand people harmonized with it.
Drawing the Shang and striking the Jiao,
The crowd did not respond.
This is all because they delight in deviant sounds,
Not understanding the great extent.ğŸ”½Han Fei used the views of Guan and Qiao to belittle Yao and Shun.
Jiao Tuo used the distinctions of Mao and Zhu to criticize Zhongni.
They all indulge in the small and neglect the great.
If one hears the clear Shang note and calls it Jiao,
It is not the fault of the plucked strings,
But the listener's lack of acuity.
If one sees a jade and calls it stone,
It is not because the jade is cheap,
But because the viewer is not discerning.
The divine snake can cut and then reconnect,
But it cannot make people not cut.
The spiritual tortoise had a dream for the Song dynasty,
But it could not escape the net of Yu Que.
The great Way is non-action, not seen by the worldly.
Those praised are not considered noble.
Those disparaged are not considered lowly.
Using or not using is up to Heaven.
Practicing or not practicing depends on the times.
Belief or disbelief is one's fate.
Question:
You use the classics and commentaries to reason about the Buddha's teachings.
Your words are rich and the meaning is clear.
Your writing is abundant and the explanations are beautiful.
Are you not distorting the truth with your own eloquence?
Mouzi replied:
This is not my eloquence.
It is because I have seen widely that I am not confused.
Question:
Is there a method to seeing widely?
Mouzi said:
It comes from the Buddhist scriptures.
When I did not understand the Buddhist scriptures,
My confusion was even greater than yours.
Although I recited the Five Classics, I just considered them flowery.
They had not yet become real.
Having seen the teachings of the Buddhist scriptures,
and examined the essentials of Laozi,
I guard the nature of tranquility and peace,
and observe the practice of non-action.
Looking back at worldly affairs,ğŸ”½it is like peering into a valley from the edge of a high cliff,
or seeing a small mound from Mount Song or Mount Dai.
The Five Classics are like the five flavors,
and the Buddhist path is like the five grains.
Since I heard the Way,
it is like parting the clouds to see the bright sun,
or like holding a torch in a dark room.
Question:
You say the scriptures are like rivers and seas, and their texts are like brocade.
Why not answer my question with Buddhist scriptures,
but instead quote the Book of Poetry and the Book of History?
Do you reconcile differences to make them the same?
Mouzi replied:
The thirsty do not necessarily need rivers and seas to drink from.
The hungry do not necessarily wait for a granary to be full.
The Way is established for the wise.
Discrimination is understood by the enlightened.
Books are transmitted to the knowledgeable.
Events are clarified for the sighted.
I have drawn this matter out because I know your intention.
If you speak the words of the Buddha's scriptures,
Discussing the essentials of non-action,
It is like speaking of the five colors to the blind,
Or playing the five notes for the deaf.
Even if Shi Kuang is skillful, he cannot play a stringless zither.
Even if foxes and weasels are warm, they cannot heat a person without breath.
Gong Ming Yi plays the clear horn for an ox, but the ox eats as usual. It does not hear what is not heard by an ox, and it does not match its ears.
He then plays the sound of mosquitoes and gadflies, the cry of a solitary calf.
It immediately wags its tail, pricks up its ears, and listens attentively. Thus the Book of Poetry and the Book of Rites are for the ears of the young.
Question:
In the past, when I was in the capital,
I entered the Eastern Observation Hall and roamed the Imperial Academy.
I looked at what the outstanding scholars aimed for,
And listened to what the scholars in the forest discussed.
I have never heard of cultivating the Buddhist path as being noble,
Or of taking self-mutilation as supreme.
Why do you, my son, indulge in it?
If one's actions are confused, one changes the path.
When techniques are exhausted, they return.
Can it not be thought of?
Mouzi said:
Those who excel in change cannot be deceived by deceit; those who are proficient in the Way cannot be startled by wonders.
Those who are discerning in speech cannot be confused by words.
Those who understand righteousness cannot be moved by profit.
Laozi said:
Name is the harm to the body.
Profit is the defilement of action.
He also said:
Creating deceit and establishing strategies,
Empty and void, self-important.ğŸ”½Cultivating the rites of the inner quarters, the gatherings of the times and customs,
Attending to the gaps, striving to conform to the present age.
This is what the lower person practices.
It is what the middle person abandons.
How much more so for the vastness of the ultimate Way,
The practice of the highest sage!ğŸ”½It is as vast as the heavens,
As deep as the ocean.
It does not accord with the one who peeks over a wall, the one who counts the few feet.
It is certainly appropriate.
They see its gate, I behold its room.
They pick the flowers, I take the fruit.
They seek the complete, I guard the one.
Son, quickly change your path, I invite you to tread it.
The source of misfortune and blessings,
I do not yet know what it is like.
Question:
You use the words of the classics and histories, the elegant and beautiful teachings,
To praise the practice of the Buddha and extol his virtues.
The high ones soar above the clear clouds,
The vast ones surpass the boundaries of the earth.
Isn't it going beyond its basis and exceeding its reality?
And my criticisms have somewhat hit the mark, and that is the disease.
Mouzi said:
Alas, what I praise,
Is like adding dust and sand to Mount Song and Mount Tai,
Collecting morning dew to throw into the rivers and seas.
What you slander,ğŸ”½Is like holding a ladle and brush wanting to reduce the rivers and seas,
Stepping on a plow and hoe wanting to harm Mount Kunlun,
Turning one's palm to block the sunlight,
Raising a clod of earth to block the river's surge.
What I praise cannot make the Buddha high,
Your criticism cannot make it inferior.
Question:
The divine books of the eight immortals of the Red Pine, such as Wang Qiao, have one hundred and seventy scrolls.
Are the matters of longevity the same as the Buddhist scriptures?
Mouzi said:
Comparing them is like comparing the five hegemons to the five emperors.
Yang Huo to Confucius.
Comparing their forms is like comparing a small hill to Mount Hua.
A small stream to the Yangtze or the Yellow River.ğŸ”½Comparing their writing is like comparing a tiger skin to sheepskin.
Banded hemp to brocade.
There are ninety-six kinds of Daoism.
As for the most revered and great,
none surpasses the Buddhist Dao.
The books of immortals and spirits,
listening to them fills the ears.
Seeking their effects is like grasping at the wind and capturing a shadow.
Therefore, the Great Dao does not take them.
The state of non-action does not value them.
How can they be the same?
Question:
Those who practice the Dao sometimes abstain from grains and do not eat.
And drink alcohol and eat meat.
It is also said to be the art of Laozi.
However, Buddhism strictly prohibits alcohol and meat.
Yet they still eat grains.
How strange is this!
Mouzi said:
There are 96 different ways in the world.
Nothing is more simple and effortless than Buddhism.
I have read the chapters of Laozi from beginning to end.
I have heard of the precept against the five flavors,
But I have not seen the words to abandon the five grains.
The sage wrote the seven classics,
But there is no method to stop eating.
Laozi wrote the five thousand words,
But there is no matter of avoiding grains.
The sage said:ğŸ”½Those who eat grains are wise.
Those who eat grass are foolish.ğŸ”½Those who eat meat are brave.
Those who eat qi have long lives.
People in the world do not understand this matter.
They see the six birds closing their breath and not breathing, and do not want to eat in autumn and winter, so they imitate them.
They do not know that different species each have their own nature.
It is like a magnet attracting iron, but not being able to move a single hair.
Question:
Can grains be completely cut off or not?
Mouzi said:
When I did not understand the great Way,
I also studied this.
There are thousands and hundreds of methods for avoiding grains.
Practicing them has no effect, and there is no evidence of success.
Therefore, I abandoned it.
As for the teachers from whom I learned, there were three people.
They claimed to be 700, 500, and 300 years old respectively.
However, I studied with them.
In less than three years, they all died.
The reason for this is as follows.
It is because they cut off grains and did not eat, but consumed hundreds of fruits.
When eating meat, they piled up the plates.
When drinking wine, they emptied the cups.ğŸ”½The vital energy of grains was not sufficient, and the ears and eyes became confused and licentious.
They could not control themselves.
I asked them the reason.
They replied:
Laozi said:
Reduce it again and again,
Until reaching non-action.
They merely reduced it day by day.
However, I observe that
they only increase their burdens and do not reduce them.
Therefore, they all die before reaching the end of their natural lifespan.
Moreover, Yao, Shun, the Duke of Zhou, and Confucius each did not live a hundred years.
Yet in the latter age, the foolish and deluded
wish to take elixirs and practice fasting for nourishment to seek endless longevity.
Alas!
A question was asked:
People who practice the Way say
that they can avoid illness and be free from sickness.
Is it possible to be cured without using needles and medicine?
Why do Buddhists use needles and medicine when they are sick?ğŸ”½Mouzi replied:
Laozi said:
When things are strong, they become old.
This is called not being in accord with the Way.
Those who are not in accord with the Way age quickly. Only those who have attained the Way do not give birth.
Those who do not give birth also do not grow strong.
Those who do not grow strong also do not age.
Those who do not age also do not get sick.
Those who do not get sick also do not decay. Therefore, Laozi considered the body to be a great affliction.ğŸ”½When King Wu was sick, the Duke of Zhou prayed for his life.
When Zhongni was sick, Zilu asked to pray for him.
I see that all sages have illnesses.
I have yet to see one without illness.
Shen Nong tasted herbs and almost died dozens of times.
Huangdi bowed his head.
He received acupuncture from Qibing.
These three sages.
How could they not be like the Daoists of today?
Examine these words.
They are sufficient to be abolished.
Question:
The Dao is all non-action, one.
Why do you distinguish and list its differences?
It makes learners doubt even more.
I think it is a waste without benefit.
Mouzi said:
All are called grasses.
The natures of various grasses cannot be fully described.
All are called gold.
The natures of various golds cannot be fully described.
Similar types have different natures.
All things are like this.
How can it be limited to the Dao?
In the past, Yang and Mo blocked the way of the multitude of Confucians.
The carriage could not move forward, and people could not walk.
Meng Ke opened it up, and only then did he know where to go.
Shi Kuang played the qin, waiting for those who would appreciate it in the future.
The sages created laws, hoping that gentlemen would see them.
Jade and stone are in the same box.
Yi Dun changed his expression because of it.
Zhu and Zi compete with each other.
Zhongni sighed because of it.
The sun and moon are not not bright.
The many shades obscure their light.
The Buddha's way is not not correct.
The many private matters conceal its publicness.
Therefore, I divide and distinguish them.
Zang Wen's wisdom and Weisheng's uprightness.
Zhongni did not borrow them.
These are all the words of those who rectify the world.
What is the use of expending without benefit?
Question:
You slander immortals and suppress strange things.
You do not believe there is a way of immortality.
Why do you alone believe in the Buddha's way and think it will lead to transcendence?
The Buddha is in a foreign land.
Your feet have not trod its ground.
Your eyes do not see its place.
You merely observe its texts and believe in its practices.
Those who observe flowers cannot know the truth.
Those who look at shadows cannot discern the form.
How can it be that they are not sincere?
Mouzi said:
Confucius said:ğŸ”½Observe their reasons.
Examine their origins.
Investigate their peace.
How can people be so insignificant?
In the past, Lu Xiang asked the Duke of Zhou about governing the people.
Each knew the reason for their eventual end.ğŸ”½When Yan Yuan was riding in a carriage drawn by four horses,
he saw the driving of Dongye Bi.
He knew it would fail.
Zengzi observed the meeting between Zhu and Lu.
He illuminated the reason for their loss.
Zhongni heard the strings of Shi Kuang.
And recognized the playing of King Wen.
Ji Zi listened to music.
He examined the customs of various countries.
Why must one walk with their feet and see with their eyes?
